message: My prayers go out to all impacted by the storm that hit many parts of Georgia and Alabama on Monday night. I urge everyone to remain safe indoors until the storm passes and the affected areas are cleared of debris. If you require emergency assistance, please call 911. For non-emergency assistance, please call (229) 483-6226 or (229) 483-6227 or (229) 483-6228. For resources to deal with power outages in your home, please visit https://www.georgiapower.com/in-your-community/storm-center/.

Earlier today, a state of emergency was declared in portions of Southwest Georgia following Monday night’s storms. Baker, Calhoun, Mitchell, and Dougherty counties were included in this designation. I am working diligently with partners at the local, state, and federal level to ensure adequate assistance is made available as quickly as possible.
With cold temperatures coming this weekend and many still without electricity, there are now emergency locations offering shelter and warmth in Albany.
Cold temperatures throughout Georgia are expected this weekend. Emergency locations are offering shelter in Columbus.

I would like to extend my sincerest thanks to all who came and helped out this weekend in Albany with emergency efforts. Our emergency personnel, first-responders, and volunteers did a great job working for the community despite the cold temperatures. It was great seeing the Eastern Star Volunteers donating their time at the Albany Civic Center with Mayor Dorothy Hubbard!

I thank Governor Nathan Deal for his swift action in issuing a state of emergency in southwest Georgia. I saw the destruction in Albany firsthand when I was home this past weekend, and I am pleased that Governor Deal also will be touring the area. The scope of the damage is significant and I urge the Governor to submit a formal request to the President for federal disaster assistance as soon as possible.

I would like to sincerely thank Governor Nathan Deal and his staff for their quick response to the disaster situation in Southwest Georgia. Thousands of individuals and households were impacted by the storms. Working to secure combined federal and state assistance for impacted parties will be critical moving forward.

Today, we honor one of our nation’s most courageous and passionate leaders, Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Dr. King spent his life fighting for change, equality, and love and he knew that true strength comes from unity, not division. As we celebrate his legacy, remember that the fight for justice and freedom never ends, and we must do all we can to defend these bedrock principles.

The storms and tornadoes that struck Albany and the rest of the southwest and middle Georgia region earlier today were truly devastating. I pray for those that lost loved ones. I am working with our partners at the local, state, and federal levels to get additional assistance to the area as quickly as possible. Look after your neighbors and God Bless.

Last night, Rep. Austin Scott and Congressman Steven Palazzo joined me in leading a moment of silence on the floor of the House of Representatives to recognize and remember the victims of the storms and tornadoes that struck the Southeast region of our nation. It is now our job to ensure that all those impacted by these disasters are provided the necessary resources to recover and rebuild as soon as possible.

I am relieved to hear that the initial request for federal assistance has been approved by the President. Middle and Southwest Georgia have faced destructive storms and tornadoes twice this month, and federal resources will be vital for the region’s recovery. I urge the President to also approve the second request for federal assistance for those that were impacted by the tornadoes and storms that pummeled the area on January 22.

A second federal major disaster declaration has been issued for additional counties in Middle and Southwest Georgia impacted by the major storms and tornadoes on January 22, 2017. This declaration opens up potential eligibility for FEMA Individual Assistance for Berrien, Cook, Crisp, Dougherty, Turner, and Wilcox counties.  Further information on FEMA eligibility, local resources, and the application process can be found at www.disasterassistance.gov or by calling 1-800-621-FEMA (3362), or 1-800-462-7585 (TTY) for the hearing and speech impaired. Those who use 711 or Video Relay Service (VRS) can call 1-800-621-3362. The toll-free telephone numbers are currently operational from 7:00 a.m. to 11:00 p.m. (Eastern Time) seven days a week.
The tornado in Albany has tragically claimed another life. My heartfelt prayers go out to the family of Patricia Ann Gohman.

Kudos to former Acting AG Sally Yates! She demonstrated integrity, courage, and commitment to the U.S. Constitution, to justice, and to the rule of law!  A legal analysis of the President's Executive Order on Immigration can be found on my website below:

Last week, I was honored to receive the Army’s Distinguished Civilian Service Medal. Throughout my congressional career, I have worked to ensure our military personnel are provided all the resources they need. They are the ones that tirelessly carry out the mission day-in and day-out, and it is important that we never forget or overlook their commitment and sacrifice in defense of our nation.

I am proud to begin serving as Ranking Member of the House Appropriations Agriculture Subcommittee. Tune in to watch the subcommittee’s first hearing of the year, which is with the U.S. Department of Agriculture Office of Inspector General.

It was great spending time with students from Fort Middle School during last week’s Black History Observance Breakfast in Columbus. A big thanks to Rep. Cedric Richmond, current Chair of the Congressional Black Caucus, for joining us!
March is National Kidney Month! 1 in 3 American adults is at risk for kidney disease. To learn more about how to get checked, visit https://www.niddk.nih.gov/.

On #InternationalWomensDay, we celebrate the invaluable contributions of the women around us and all over the world – past, present, and future. We must redouble our efforts to fight for women’s rights and gender equality!

DEADLINE: March 27, 2017 is the deadline to register with FEMA for disaster assistance for residents of Berrien, Cook, Crisp, Dougherty, Thomas, Turner, Wilcox, and Worth counties.   Residents can register online at www.DisasterAssistance.gov or by calling the FEMA Helpline at 800-621-3362; downloading the FEMA app at https://asd.fema.gov/inter/locator/home.htm; or visiting a Disaster Recovery Center. To find the nearest center, visit https://asd.fema.gov/inter/locator/home.htm.
It was an honor to speak last Sunday at the 11th Annual Men & Women’s Day Service at the Fourth Street Missionary Baptist Church in Columbus.
I would like to congratulate Kevin Boykin, CEO of Path-Tec in Midland, Georgia for being named the 2017 Georgia Small Business Person of the Year by the U.S. Small Business Administration!

Happy National Ag Day! Thanks to all the farmers, ranchers, and producers who are the backbone of our nation’s agriculture industry. I am proud to be from a state that is instrumental in feeding people throughout the United States and the world.

It is for good reason that TrumpCare was withdrawn from the House floor. It was opposed by AARP, the American Medical Association, the American Hospital Association, nurses and physicians, patients, consumer groups, and the citizenry at large. If we want to make America great again, we need to ensure that it is healthy. TrumpCare would have done the opposite.

Today, I was presented with the 2017 Distinguished Community Health Advocate award by the National Association of Community Health Centers (NACHC). I am truly grateful for this award and will continue to support our communities and health centers. Thank you NACHC!

As a member of the House Appropriations Committee, and the top Democrat on the Agriculture Appropriations Subcommittee, I look forward to working with the administration, and with my congressional colleagues on both sides of the aisle, to formulate a budget that protects and strengthens rural communities. It is imperative that we craft a budget that recognizes not only the importance of a strong national defense, but also the importance of strong communities, strong schools, and a strong agricultural base.
April is Donate Life Month. Visit organdonor.gov to learn more about helping to save lives by registering as an organ donor.

I look forward to seeing everyone tomorrow at the Lake Seminole Hydrilla Town Hall. The event will be held at the Seminole County Courthouse. I will be joined by Colonel James DeLapp, Commander of the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers Mobile District, who will provide the community with an update on the Army Corps’ plan to address Hydrilla growth this season and beyond.
It was an honor and privilege to meet with students at Cairo High School earlier today. The students of today are the leaders of tomorrow.

It was a privilege to welcome Senator Bob Dole to the National Infantry Museum at Fort Benning today. Senator Dole, a World War II veteran, attended Officer Candidate School here at Fort Benning in 1944. It was a pleasure to have him back for a visit!

It was a pleasure to meet with newly sworn-in U.S. Department of Agriculture Secretary Sonny Perdue this morning. I look forward to working together to ensure our farmers, ranchers, foresters, agribusinesses, and consumers have the resources they need to prosper in today’s competitive and global environment.

I am deeply saddened to learn of the death of 1st Lieutenant Weston Lee. He served our country as an Army Ranger and an officer and paid the ultimate sacrifice. On behalf of all Americans, I extend heartfelt condolences to his family and friends and our deepest gratitude for his service and sacrifice.

I strongly opposed the House passage of the healthcare legislation to dismantle the Affordable Care Act. This bill jeopardizes the healthcare of Americans across the country. If this legislation is also approved by the Senate and signed into law, it is anticipated that 24 million Americans would lose their health insurance.   I adamantly urge my colleagues in the Senate to reject this disastrous piece of legislation, and I call on the House, the Senate, and the administration to instead come together to improve the Affordable Care Act by fixing its flaws and by building on the great strides it has already made toward providing affordable healthcare to all Americans.

I look forward to discussing the issues facing Georgia’s 2nd Congressional District this coming Tuesday at our Town Hall in Columbus. The Town Hall begins at 5:30pm and will be held at the Columbus Public Library.
Looking forward to seeing everyone at our Town Hall tonight at 5:30 p.m. at the Columbus Public Library. I will be taking a question from Facebook so please ask your questions in the comments below!

Wishing a happy Military Spouse Appreciation Day to each and every one of our military spouses! The strength of our military is drawn from the strength of their families and we thank these silent heroes for their support and sacrifices.

June 19 is the deadline to file with U.S. Small Business Administration for federal economic injury disaster loans in Chattahoochee, Muscogee, and Talbot counties in Georgia as a result of the drought that began on Aug. 23, 2016. For more information and to apply online, please visit https://disasterloan.sba.gov/ela
NA
As a reminder, I will be holding a Town Hall Meeting in Macon this evening! I look forward to seeing everyone at Central Georgia Technical College from 5:30pm-7:30pm.
NA

There is still time available to apply for the Veterans Upward Bound (VUB) Program!  VUB helps provide military veterans with the necessary skills to improve acceptance rates into colleges and universities, as well as degree completion rates. The application deadline is June 21, 2017.   The application for Veterans Upward Bound grants is available below:
NA

There is time still available to register for the U.S. Department of Agriculture 2017 Agriculture Census!  USDA conducts an Agriculture Census every five years to get a complete count of America’s farms and ranches and the people that operate them. This is your opportunity to be loud and proud about the phenomenal agricultural products, such as the food, fuel, feed, and fiber you produce for this country and abroad. Results will be used to influence important decisions including the Farm Bill, rural economic development, research, telecommunications connectivity, transportation locations, as well as young and veteran farmer programs. The registration deadline: June 30, 2017. For more information: https://www.agcounts.usda.gov/cgi-bin/counts.

Middle and South Georgia is known for its extreme summer heat and humidity. Swimming and other water activities are a popular way to cool off in extreme heat. Swimming is also a great form of exercise and can be done by just about anyone, regardless of athletic level.  As June is National Safety Month, I want to share with you some tips to keep you and your family safe in the sun and water this summer!

This bill takes several steps to provide the Armed Forces with the facilities needed to support our service members and their families wherever they work, train, and live. I am pleased that the bill provides a total of $202.9 million toward military construction needs in Georgia. This includes $10.8 million for a new Air Traffic Control Tower at Fort Benning to support mission readiness, which was the Army's number one construction priority. The bill also includes $43.3 million in funding to repair damage to the Marine Corps Logistics Base in Albany, which was struck by severe storms and tornadoes last January.

I thank the Association of Defense Communities for putting together yesterday’s panel to discuss the evolving needs of military families. We had a robust discussion on how to support the needs of service members and their families. Blue Star Families National Military Family Association Waynesville R-VI School District
NA

Today is #PTSDAwarenessDay.   PTSD not only affects survivors of combat, but also survivors of natural disasters, crime, or serious accidents. It can happen to anyone, and most importantly, it’s not a sign of weakness.  For more information on symptoms, treatment and/or helping a family member or friend, you can visit https://www.ptsd.va.gov/public/index.asp.

It was a pleasure to meet with representatives from GIB-Georgia Industries for the Blind and National Industries for the Blind. Thank you for all the work you do on behalf of people who are blind, and for inviting me to speak at your annual Day on Capitol Hill.

Happy Fourth of July! On this day, 241 years ago, our Founding Fathers ratified the Declaration of Independence, a document that would change the course of history. May we never forget the incredible privilege it is to live in the United States. God bless you and our wonderful country!

I was heartbroken to learn a USMC transport plane crashed in western Mississippi yesterday afternoon. My thoughts and prayers are with the friends and families of the fallen 16 service members who were on board. I stand with all who have been affected by this tragedy.

It was a pleasure working with the U.S. Department of Veterans Affairs and the National Academic Affiliations Council at the Diversity and Inclusion Summit. We are committed to addressing health care disparities and inequities, and further improving partnerships with Historically Black Colleges and Universities.

The Cotton Ginning Cost Share Program has proven itself to be an effective tool to protect our cotton farms from economic devastation. I urge the President to continue this program to ensure the availability of U.S. cotton for those manufacturers and consumers that rely on this vital agricultural product.
Many brave citizens have fought and even died for the right to vote over America’s history. Let’s move forward, not backward for #VotingRights

Thank you to the National Council on Independent Living for inviting me to speak at their rally today and for all the invaluable work they do advocating for people living with disabilities. For the past 35 years, NCIL has been working hard to make sure everyone’s voice is heard.

I thoroughly enjoyed hosting Tommy Sheppard MP, a Member of the UK Parliament of the Scottish National Party, earlier this week as a part of the State Department’s annual program to nurture the United Kingdom and the United States’ special relationship. I’m looking forward to watching his continued successes in Parliament.

Today, the Muscogee County School District held a ribbon cutting and preview for the new Rainey-McCullers School of the Arts. I thank the school system for inviting me to speak. I am excited for the success these students will have and the community, artistry, and creativity this school will foster.

I am heartbroken over the lives lost this weekend due to the hateful and violent protests by white supremacists and Neo-Nazis in Charlottesville. Of the millions of Americans who fought Nazism in World War II, hundreds of thousands died or were wounded. The beliefs of Nazis were and remain evil. We must stand together against such evil and continue to love one another.    “We love because he first loved us. If anyone says, “I love God,” and hates his brother, he is a liar; for he who does not love his brother whom he has seen cannot love God whom he has not seen. And this commandment we have from him: whoever loves God must also love his brother.” 1 John 4:19-21
My thoughts and prayers are with our sailors aboard the USS John S. McCain and their families.

Congratulations to A. West Enterprise, which was founded in 2009 in a barn in Albany, Georgia, for being awarded a $15 million contract by the U.S. Army. Under this contract, A. West Enterprise will perform lighting and electrical upgrades to Sheppard Air Force Base.

Regardless of dietary preferences or political affiliations, we all need to eat to survive, and I am honored to tour vital agricultural sites with my friend, Rep. Jimmy Panetta.   California’s 20th and Georgia’s 2nd congressional districts are alike in that agriculture does not just live here, it thrives here. Going into the next Farm Bill and working to closeout FY18 appropriations, I see no better time to ensure we are responsibly resourcing industries, programs, and efforts that will keep U.S. agriculture flourishing and competitive on the worldwide stage.
I applaud our first responders, volunteers, and community members for their tremendous response to Hurricane Harvey. My prayers go out to all impacted in Texas and Louisiana.
Guidance from FEMA on how to help those impacted by Hurricane Harvey:

Right now, WALB News 10 Weather is reporting that Irma will head to South Georgia next week. Dangerous and life-threatening tropical storm force winds are expected to arrive by Monday. Now is a good time to begin making necessary preparations.
Governor Deal has expanded the state of emergency for Hurricane Irma to include all 29 counties in Georgia's 2nd Congressional District, as well as additional surrounding counties.
NA
Hurricane Irma Information from Georgia Emergency Management Agency/Homeland Security:

Today, I join all Americans in remembrance of those who lost their lives and all those who bravely responded on 9/11. This day changed the course of our nation. Many innocent lives were lost, and families were torn apart. They will never be forgotten and will live in our prayers and actions.   It was a trying day in our history. However, in responding to this tragedy, our nation came together. We showed solidarity in the face of adversity and helped our fellow neighbors. We showed the strength of our common bond as Americans.   On this 16th anniversary of September 11, 2001, let us pause to remember all those who have sacrificed, and who continue to sacrifice, to preserve this great nation’s freedom.   May God continue to bless the United States of America.

Happy National Peanut Day! Georgia is the number one peanut producer in the United States, producing almost half of all the peanuts in the country. Whether you like your peanuts boiled, roasted, salted; or your peanut butter chunky or smooth please join us in celebrating peanuts today!

Congresswoman Cathy McMorris Rodgers and I will be holding the Military Family Summit on October 17 to discuss the pressing issues facing our military families.   We hope you all can attend this event at the National Infantry Museum in Columbus, GA! You can register by following the link below:

For agricultural communities affected by #Harvey, #Irma, and #Maria; remember to contact the @USDA. They are here to help! Georgia, Florida, and Texas residents see the attached contact sheets.   Reminder: @USDA approved automatic replacement benefits for food purchased with September 2017 SNAP benefits for affected Georgia counties.

This HBCU week, I thank Fort Valley State University and Albany State University for everything they do to educate and expand young minds in Middle and Southwest Georgia.   I and a number of my staff members are proud HBCU sons and daughters. We know firsthand the importance of these institutions in providing a quality education to everyone.   #HBCUPride #HBCUWeek

I am thrilled that the U.S. Army Corps is taking decisive action to revitalize Lake Seminole and Walter F. George Lake. Addressing hydrilla growth in these two lakes will breath new life into these important resources. The action taken by the Army Corps will restore ecological balance and allow for sustainable usage of the lakes by the surrounding communities. I look forward to seeing these lakes flourish for years to come.

We must strengthen our military families by raising awareness and championing policies that support them better. The Congressional Military Family Caucus provides a venue to drive reforms that make significant impact on their lives. I hope you can take time to join us for the annual Military Family Summit on October 17. #milfam
I am extremely grateful for the visit by Myron Mixon, Mayor of Unadilla, Georgia. It was nice to have a taste of Georgia on Capitol Hill.
We have one more week until the Congressional Military Family Summit! #milfam

Because of our dedicated and hardworking farmers, Georgia contributes $71 billion annually to the state and national economy. Georgia is number one in the nation for the production of poultry, peanuts, cotton, pecans, and blueberries. I am proud to represent Georgia’s 2nd Congressional district, which leads the state in peanuts, pecans, fruits, and vegetables. Join me today in giving a well-deserved Thank you to all the growers in this great nation who tirelessly contribute to our society and economy. After all….they keep us fed. #NationalFarmersDay
NA

As Co-Chair of the Congressional Military Family Caucus and a member of the House Appropriations Subcommittee on Military Construction and Veterans Affairs, I take seriously my obligation to military families and veterans in Georgia and nationwide. It is our responsibility to listen, learn, and ensure military family voices are heard on Capitol Hill. Spousal employment, state licensure, healthcare and caregiving, and military child education provide unique challenges for military families, and as legislators, we must see to it that the policies we craft ease the burden for those families that support our national defense.

We had productive conversations at the Congressional Military Family Caucus Summit yesterday. Although we have made great strides to strengthen our military since founding the caucus in 2009, we must continue to work and make bipartisan efforts to address the most pressing concerns that impact our service members and their families.

On November 1, the VA will begin accepting applications for Veteran Identification Cards (VIC). The Veteran Identification Card will serve as proof of service in the Armed Forces and can be used to obtain discounts on goods and services offered to Veterans. Application must be submitted via VETS.gov. As part of the application process, Veterans will be asked to upload photo identification such as a Driver’s License or Passport. All honorably discharged Veterans of every era will be able to get a free photo identification card from the Department of Veterans Affairs. The VIC does not qualify Veterans for additional benefits administered by the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) and does not serve as proof for any benefits to which you may be entitled. Also, the VIC will not grant access to military post or installations. Questions about Veteran Identification Card (VIC) can be directed to VETS.gov, Help Desk 1-855-574-7286, TTY: 1-800-877-8339.   In addition, Veterans can also apply for enrollment for the Veteran Health Identification Cards (VHIC) by visiting www.va.gov/healthbenefits/enroll, calling 1-877-222-VETS (8387) on Monday – Friday from 8 a.m. to 8 p.m. ET., or by visiting a local VA medical facility. The VHIC is for identification and check-in at VA appointments and will be issued only to Veterans who are enrolled in the VA health care system. It cannot be used as a credit card or an insurance card, and it does not authorize or pay for care at non-VA facilities. Once enrollment is verified, Veterans may have their picture taken at local VA medical center, so that a VHIC can be mailed to them. Veterans will have to upload a copy of their driver’s license or passport, as well as a photo, in order to obtain this card.
Open Enrollment in the ACA Health Insurance Marketplace starts November 1 and ends December 15. Need help going through the process to #GetCovered? https://localhelp.healthcare.gov/#/
Open Enrollment for health insurance is shorter this year than in the past – November 1 to December 15. Don’t miss your chance to #GetCovered. https://localhelp.healthcare.gov/#/

I was honored to participate in the groundbreaking for the Dwight D. Eisenhower Memorial. President Eisenhower was a tremendous hero and leader for our country. Since the beginning of my tenure on the Dwight D. Eisenhower Memorial Commission, I have worked hard to turn this project into a reality.
My heart goes out to the victims and the families and friends of those who were killed and injured in the Sutherland Springs, Texas church shooting.

It was an honor speaking with distinguished veterans, service members, and over 800 Junior ROTC cadets yesterday during the Thanking Our Heroes event at the National Infantry Museum. I am grateful for the selfless service of our nation's veterans, the commitment of our men and women in uniform, and the passion of tomorrow's military leaders. These individuals represent the past, present, and future of the greatest military on the earth.
This year’s Diwali on the Hill was an enlightening experience for all. I am honored to have been able to celebrate the holiday with our Indian friends on the Hill!
I led 120 of my colleagues in writing a letter to U.S. Secretary of Labor Acosta, which successfully secured a reversal of the proposed reductions of more than 4,600 student training slots.
FACT: 8-in-10 people who signed up to #GetCovered for 2017 received financial help.  Open Enrollment for 2018 ends December 15! www.HealthCare.gov

I was honored to attend the Medal of Honor Ceremony for the five courageous United States Capitol Police officers who risked their lives to save others during the tragic shooting at the congressional baseball game practice on June 14.

With both Veterans Day and Native American Heritage Month occurring during November, I would like to take this time to honor Native American Code Talkers. During World Wars I and II, Native American soldiers, sailors and marines developed a secure line of communication by utilizing their native languages to establish a series of unique codes that saved lives and won battles.

Today, the United States Marine Corps celebrates its 242nd birthday! With faithful service to our great nation since 1775, I say with great pride, Happy Birthday Marines!  Marine Corps Logistics Base Albany
To over 20 million veterans in the United States including the 60,000 veterans who live in Second Congressional District of Georgia, I thank you for your service and sacrifice to our country.

Tonight, I will join my fellow co-chair on the Congressional Military Family Caucus, Congresswoman Cathy McMorris Rodgers , at the Blue Star Families’ 2017 Annual Military Family Lifestyle Survey Launch and Reception. The survey provides a comprehensive understanding of the experiences and challenges encountered by military families.

On November 13, Secretary Perdue designated 83 counties affected by Hurricane Irma as primary natural disaster areas. Under a Secretarial disaster designation, farm operators in primary and neighboring counties are eligible to be considered for assistance from the Farm Service Agency. This assistance includes emergency loans, provided that all eligibility requirements are met. Farmers in eligible counties have 8 months from the date of a Secretarial disaster declaration to apply for emergency loans.
FACT: Many people who signed up to #GetCovered for 2017 only paid $50-$100/month in premiums. www.HealthCare.gov.  Open Enrollment ends December 15!

I was pleased to deliver the keynote address at the Job Corps Leadership Summit yesterday.  As the Co-Chair of the Friends of Job Corps Congressional Caucus, I strongly support this program and I believe that it provides undeserved youth with the skills and training that they need to be successful.
NA

Thank you to Ms. KateLynn DeStefano and Marion County High School for inviting me to speak with them this morning about government. It’s never too early (or too late) to get involved and make a difference.

Congratulations to Springdale Elementary School Macon, GA, Robert A. Cross Middle Magnet School, Lee County High School, Aaron Cohn Middle School, Britt David Magnet Academy, Columbus High School, Johnson Elementary School, and Byron Middle School for being recognized as Georgia's 2017 Single Statewide Accountability System Awards Schools. I'm so proud of the schools in our district.

This Thanksgiving Day, I am thankful for my family, my friends, my staff, and the opportunity to serve the wonderful constituents of the 2nd Congressional District. Please have a safe and enjoyable Thanksgiving and keep those who were not able to spend the day with their loved ones in mind.
Important Open Enrollment facts: Start- November 1 End- December 15 #GetCovered Need more information: www.HealthCare.gov

Congratulations to Clarke County School District, Westside High School: Home of the Seminoles, and Crisp County School System for being named the Innovation Fund Implementation & Scaling Grantees for November 2017 by The Governor's Office of Student Achievement.

USDA has been called upon to help agricultural and rural communities across this nation affected by numerous disasters. This country has suffered from devastating tornadoes in Georgia, Texas, Oklahoma, Mississippi, Wisconsin, and Louisiana; wildfires in the West; and catastrophic hurricanes extending from Texas to Georgia and the Caribbean.   Our nation’s resolve and commitment to take care of its own is being tested, and I, for one, do not want to see us fail. I am looking forward to working together, along with my distinguished subcommittee colleagues, to ensure that all the needs are met and that they are met in a timely manner.
Open Enrollment for the ACA Health Insurance Marketplace ends December 15. Next Friday is the last day to #GetCovered! https://www.HealthCare.gov/

Thank you to 21st Century Partnership, Robins Regional Chamber, and The Association of Old Crows for hosting the Robins AFB Breakfast this morning. With its logistical and maintenance facilities, Robins Air Force Base, Georgia serves as an integral part of our national defense and a key part of the Middle Georgia community. Robins Air Force base generates 56,000 jobs, has an economic impact of $2.86 billion, and serves as home of the Joint Surveillance Target Attack Radar System (J-STARS). It is a multi-functional installation with a capacity to grow, and has the backing of a strong defense community. I stand committed to ensuring this installation receives the resources it needs to thrive in today's security environment.

Today, I had the pleasure of meeting with Commissioner Scott Gottlieb of the U.S. Food and Drug Administration  to discuss compounding, the new drug approval process for nicotine replacement, and efforts to lower nicotine to combat addiction to combustible cigarettes.

On this day 76 years ago, the U.S. Pacific Fleet was attacked at Pearl Harbor. Americans were killed and wounded, battleships were sunk, airfields were damaged. America, and the world, were changed forever. Today, let us take the time to remember those heroic souls who stood up for our country, those who lost their lives, and those who lost their loved ones on December 7, 1941 – a date which will live in infamy.

It was a pleasure to speak at this year's Annual Rural Lenders' Roundtable. Thank you to all of the lenders, brokers, and processors in attendance for the discussion on efforts to invest in rural America. I am honored I had the opportunity to address the 2018 Farm Bill and 2018 Budget and their impact on this great nation.
Did you know that you can still sign up for health insurance through December 15? Our office is here to help- it’s easier than you think! https://bishop.house.gov/

Today, UNCF released a landmark study, HBCUs Make America Strong: The Positive Economic Impact of Historically Black Colleges and Universities, demonstrating  the positive effects of HBCU-related spending on Georgia’s economy #HBCUStrong  http://images.uncf.org/production/HBCU_Consumer_Brochure_FINAL_APPROVED.pdf?_ga=2.12307828.1169572269.1513029557-95785688.1513029557

As an alumnus of Morehouse College, I know firsthand the important contributions HBCUs have made in educating, training, and empowering outstanding leaders. I am proud to be an HBCU alumnus and to have the opportunity to represent Albany State University and Fort Valley State University. #HBCUStrong

As your Representative in Congress, I take pride in keeping you up-to-date on important issues facing our state and nation.  From our economy to education, from agriculture to national security, I can help you navigate how the issues before Congress impact you and your family.    Also, as your voice in our nation’s capital, my job is to listen to you and to your concerns. Our office sends monthly E-Newsletters to keep you updated on activities in Washington, D.C. and Georgia, and to ask for your thoughts.  Follow this link to subscribe to our E-Newsletter: https://bishop.house.gov/contact/newsletter
I would like to wish a Happy Hanukkah to all my friends in the Jewish community.
Happy 381st  birthday to the proud men and women of the National Guard. Thank you for your selfless service and sacrifices.

Yesterday, I joined Democratic Whip Steny Hoyer and my fellow members of the Blue Dog Coalition to discuss our nation’s difficult fiscal situation. At over $20.5 trillion, the current federal debt is simply unsustainable. The proposed tax bill provides tax cuts for the wealthiest of the wealthy on the backs of our children, grandchildren, and the middle class. It explodes the national debt and puts budgetary pressure on key programs, including Social Security and Medicare. As an institution, we are at a moment of truth. It is past time to put our political differences aside, and to finally find common ground to address the national debt and get our fiscal house in order.
I am deeply disappointed in the Federal Communications Commission's  decision today to repeal #NetNeutrality. All citizens should have fair and equal access to the internet.
Open Enrollment in the Health Insurance Market ends TODAY! #GetCovered www.HealthCare.gov/

I have stated numerous times that I do support tax relief for Georgia families. However, it needs to be fair, balanced, and fiscally responsible both in the short and the long term. The benefits must be shared among Georgians of all income levels rather than just concentrated at the top. The tax legislation approved by the U.S. House of Representatives today fails this test.  As an institution, we in Congress are at a moment of truth. The time is now to put our political differences aside, and to find common ground on a rational tax package that is fiscally responsible, grows the economy, creates jobs, and improves the lives of all Americans.
The Children’s Health Insurance Program (CHIP) will be extended into next year. This vital program provides health insurance to 9 million children, including 130,000 children in Georgia.
